speaker: Rob
text: And I'm Rob.

speaker: Sam
text: Before you got your first job, Rob, did you do any work experience?

speaker: Rob
text: I think I may have done a day or two at some companies, just shadowing, watching how they did things – but nothing much more than that.

speaker: internships
text: Some companies offer students or recent graduates what they call internships. These are extended periods of work experience where someone can be working full-time without an actual contract and in many cases without even being paid.

speaker: Rob
text: Ah – yes. This is a bit of a problem, isn’t it? Some companies are being accused of using students and graduates as cheap or free labour.

speaker: internships
text: Yes, although the counter argument is that internships are valuable experience for people who need it before they can get a ‘real’ job. Well, we’ll look at this topic a little more after this week’s quiz question. On the topic of business and companies, which is the oldest stock exchange in the world? Is it:

speaker: internships
text: A: Bombay

text: C: Amsterdam

speaker: internships
text: What do you think, Rob?

speaker: Rob
text: Tricky, because I was expecting London on that list. I’m going to take a guess then at Amsterdam.

speaker: internshipsinternships
text: OK. Well, I will reveal the answer later in the programme. James Turner is the chief executive of an education charity. Recently he took part in a discussion on the BBC radio programme You and Yours, on the topic of internships. What does he think is a big issue with unpaid internships?

speaker: internshipsocial mobilityrules out
text: In many careers we’re now seeing that it’s almost as an expectation that a young person does an internship before they stand a chance of getting that first full-time job in that profession. And the issue with that from a sort of social mobility point of view is that a substantial proportion of those internships are unpaid and that effectively rules out those who can’t afford to work for free.

speaker: internships
text: So what is the problem with unpaid internships, Rob?

speaker: internshiprules outinternship
text: Well, if you can’t afford to work for free, it makes it very difficult to do an internship – particularly in expensive cities like London. This excludes, or rules out a lot of people from the benefits of an internship.

speaker: social mobility
text: This is bad for social mobility, which is the ability of people to move to higher, better paid levels in society. So the poorer you are the more difficult it can be to get a good job, even if you have the ability.

speaker: Rob
text: Could you afford to work for free here in London, Sam?

speaker: internship internship
text: No, I can barely afford to live in London as it is, so the idea of doing an unpaid internship would not appeal to me at all. Turner goes on to talk about other issues that are also problematic in internship programmes.

speaker: internshipsestablishedrules outwell-connectedopendoors
text: Too often internships are open to those with established connections in the professions and again that rules out those young people who don’t have the well-connected families or friends who can open those doors for them.

speaker: Sam
text: So what are these other issues?

speaker: established connections
text: In many cases he says that internship opportunities are only available to those with established connections to the company or industry. This means they have some pre-existing link with the company, for example, through family or friends’ families.

speaker: well-connected
text: Yes, it’s a lot easier if your family is well-connected, if it has a lot of contacts and links to a particular company or important people in that company.

speaker: open doorsopen doors
text: These links make it easier to open doors to the opportunity. To open doors is an expression that means to get access to.

speaker: Sam
text: So it seems that to be able to do an unpaid internships you need to have a fair bit of money and to get an internship in the first place you may need to have a previous link to the company through a family connection, for example.

speaker: Rob
text: So the system would seem to be difficult for poorer families and make it more difficult for students without those resources or connections to get on the job ladder. Here’s James Turner again.

speaker: internshipsestablishedwell-connectedopendoors
text: Too often internships are open to those with established connections in the professions and again that rules out those young people who don’t have the well-connected families or friends who can open those doors for them.

speaker: internships
text: Right, let’s have a look again at today’s vocabulary. We’ve been talking about internships which are periods of work at companies as a way for students or new graduates to get experience in a particular field.

speaker: social mobility
text: If they are unpaid it can make social mobility very difficult. This is the movement from a lower social level to a higher one and it’s difficult as poorer candidates can’t afford to work for free.

speaker: rules  out
text: Yes, the cost rules them out, it excludes them from the opportunity.

speaker: established
text: What helps is if you have established connections with a company. This refers to previous or pre-existing links with a company.

speaker: well-connectedopen doors
text: And also if your family is well-connected, if it has good connections, for example if your father plays golf with the CEO, it can open doors, or in other words, it can make it easier to get into the company.
